question_details.query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two randomized, controlled studies evaluated treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium: in Canada, treatment at the time of white-nose syndrome infection increased survival and reduced disease symptoms in caged bats, whereas treatment 21 days prior did not increase survival and was associated with worse symptoms; in the USA, treatment increased survival for free-flying bats within a mine but did not increase survival for caged bats and resulted in similar disease severity to untreated bats (2008). No studies were found that evaluated vaccinating bats against the white-nose syndrome pathogen (1011), decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves (2006), restricting human access to bat caves (1010), or breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome (2009).

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Increasing turbine cut-in speeds reduced bat fatalities in 10 of 12 studies (replicated, randomized, controlled or before-and-after) in the USA and Canada; two studies found no reduction with small sample sizes or short treatment durations [1960]. Preventing blades from turning at low wind speeds (feathering), or feathering combined with higher cut-in speeds, reduced bat fatalities in five of six studies in the USA and Canada; one study with automatic feathering found no reduction [970]. Slowing blade rotation at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities in one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada [2939]. Automatically reducing blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high reduced bat fatalities in two replicated studies (Germany and USA), for all bats combined and for five species [971]. Ultrasonic deterrents at turbines showed mixed results across three replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the USA, with reductions ranging from 2151% in one year to variable outcomes (from 2% more to 64% fewer fatalities) in another; species-specific effects were also mixed [968].
